Thomas Guerrier: One short film at a time

21/11/2012

Thomas Guerrier talks to Steven Roberts about short film, his love of thrillers, and why the film industry isn't as scary as it looks. (Thumbnail credit Photo Credit: Sebastian Solberg )

Image by

By undefined undefined

Short film is not one's first port of call when it comes to Friday's film night. But the many thriller-lovers out there should not overlook films by Thomas and Simon Guerrier. Cleaning Up assassinated its challengers for best thriller at ASFF 2011, and, as Shortcutz London award-recipients and nominees for East End Festival's Best UK Short Film 2012, it hasn't done badly in the award arena either. The breakthrough moment was even more marked due to the presence of an experienced actor, Mark Gatiss, who was cast as the film's suited assassin. Gatiss has already proven he can do enigmatic well in his role as Mycroft Holmes in BBC One's Sherlock, and should be an all-round professional when it comes to darker material with The League of Gentlemen, Doctor Who, Jekyll and Psychoville among his acting (and screenwriting) TV career. It follows that both on and off the set his presence gave educational value to Thomas' directorship of the film: "Gatiss had such etiquette in the way he worked. From our first meeting he treated me like I was the director, like I was in charge. Not only was I working with a great actor, but how he carried himself off camera was for me a good learning experience."
"Cleaning up was the first time we did it properly. It was the best thing we ever did. The first films I made I never sent to a festival because they were quite embarrassing..."
If the calibre of the actors getting involved in Guerrier Brothers film projects is anything to go by, the appeal of their second thriller - Revealing Diary - is helped by another familiar face, Ciara Janson of Hollyoaks fame. However, this film shares with Cleaning Up the reassuring quality of being greater than the sum of its parts. Same ambition to chill with new inspired substance, Revealing Diary is an intelligent five-minute piece that dabbles in the trendy psycho-thriller subgenre and provokes in viewers unsettling questions that linger longer than its running time. The downright creepiness of the film becomes evident as the credits roll. Sadly, the film was beaten by ASFF thriller champion of 2012, Augenblicke (Martin Bargiel). It's a tough competition and the sheer amount of talent that Thomas and Simon are competing with is perhaps indicative of the digital age, "I think there's never been a better time to do film because you can make something and get it out there so easily, the technology is much more accessible." Of course, skilled entrants can only make a festival more exciting and may represent something of a cultural flowering in the world of short film, "although on the one hand it's more competitive, I think you're going to see much greater variety." Since there is a mounting creative interest in the medium, your first submission to a short film festival is not a task to be taken likely and does require some independent learning beforehand. For many film-makers it can be a milestone in their career, a moment when they are encouraged, or discouraged, to move on to feature length projects. When asked whether this is a natural progression, Thomas answered "kind of, yes. As with any career you take little steps. The first films I made I never sent to a festival because they were quite embarrassing, but you learn. You start to understand the process: you take a few duff shots and ask 'well why didn't that work?'. Little by little, you get to festivals, and then your responsibilities grow." Will the Guerriers grow to be as big as the Coen Brothers? Thomas has his eyes on larger projects, but for now, the message seems to be concentrate on your craft - walk before you try to run and learn from your bruises. One thing Thomas is sure of: "Cleaning up was the first time we did it properly and it was the best thing we ever did." On balance, Thomas believes that working your way up into the film industry is not all gladiatorial resolve and battle scars. He was particularly interested in how short film competitions can act as a sympathetic forum for the next generation of creative minds slaving away in the studio. "A lot of the time it can be a fairly lonely process, but the fun thing is a film festival can be a great opportunity for film makers to meet up and see other people's work. For me that can be very encouraging and supportive." One excellent example is Virgin Media Shorts, whose motto is 'championing undiscovered talent'. This ethos showed its material worth for the Guerrier Brothers when they got neatly bound up in related press coverage for their comedy, The Plotters. This film plays with the famous van de Passe engraving of the Gunpowder conspirators, whose near-identical appearances confuse their leader Guy and send the dialogue into a downward spiral of criss-crossing silliness. I should also mention that Simon not only co-wrote but played a minor acting role in the film (not content with playing a bodyguard in Cleaning Up), a position which Thomas says he unfortunately doesn't have time in the day for. Thanks to Virgin Media the short is likely to reach an audience who can appreciate the Guerrier Brothers whether they're behind or placed before the camera. If publicised events can encourage a discourse between film directors and fans, as well as between film makers of a shared cadre, it has to be said that York's ASFF, Thomas' favourite event, does particularly well on both counts. "It's got the perfect balance, both for how it helps new film makers and for how very open it is to the public." The venue for the 2012 awards ceremony was the Yorkshire Museum and there was certainly a healthy mix of film makers, film fans and more serious aspirants to the director's chair milling around in the airy Roman exhibit, chatting away beneath the city's old Ninth Legion Hispana gateway. The Guerrier Brothers themselves began as humble fans of media entertainment. "As kids we were doing comics, stories and we were into magazines - all that kind of stuff - so we've always done it." Talking to an up-and-coming film maker gives you a sense of their own cautious understanding of personal development. "There was an eight year period when we were not doing anything and we thought maybe we should go and get proper jobs. But then we said, 'hang on a minute, all we ever do is think and talk about this stuff (film) so why we don't we have a go?" A shared enthusiasm for film with a good dose of brotherly comradeship defines their approach, even if the two began working apart, with Thomas starting out in special effects (for the Harry Potter films). While amicable relations are fundamental, the Guerrier's have effectively taken their familial connection into a professional context where there are clear expectations of one another. When asked about the theme of identity that may or may not lie at the written roots of their work, Thomas naturally replied "all the stories are written by Simon so you would have to speak to him." As a director, in charge of drawing the ideas of a film together into a polished viewable product, Thomas is wary of having a feel for the story but mainly to capture and convey it for the enjoyment of film fans: "the main thing is just to have a good sense of story and narrative, and so, really respect your audience." The most widely recognised siblings in the film industry right now are the Coen Brothers, but the Guerriers might find a comparison with Ethan and Joel Coen both odd, and flattering, due to their different approaches to their work. Nevertheless, both partnerships share the ability to collaborate on a shared project, and this is not to be underestimated. While Thomas and Simon operate on a smaller scale, keeping it short and sweet is a priority rather than a crutch, if not just for the ease of proving themselves at the next applicable festival. Even then, as late as 2007 the Coen's themselves produced a short film called World Cinema to commemorate the 60th anniversary of Cannes Film Festival, which also judges short films. Widely respected as the medium is, we need small-scale celebrations like ASFF to reveal the raw worth of entry-level short films. When titles like Cleaning Up and Revealing Diary lie at the heart of the festival, we know the Guerriers and their ambitious competitors are on to a good thing - "if you want to get into the industry the best way to do it is to make a good short film." The Coens' New World Cinema is about a man who goes to see a movie. Before the punter even gets into the screening room he has to decide what to watch, and asks a few misplaced questions about Ceylan's Climates. The enthusiastic ticket seller is forced to give a brief summary of the film, but is inevitably unable to capture its true glory in such few words. The twist is that the untrained cinema-goer thwarts our expectations by proving he is capable of opening his mind to a powerful film, even if he's a little bashful about it. Suffice to say, it's well worth checking out some short films if like me you hadn't until now. Thomas' favourite showing at ASFF '12 was Home by T. Gleeson, but watching Revealing Diary at GuerrierBrothers.com is also one of the best ways to start. And please, don't be satisfied with my ticket-seller summary.
